Derivation for long and short durations
Centroid or average catchment use for small catchments or catchments with low variability (5% or 10 % test based on max - min)

Use of BoM gridded rainfall- New BoM product schedule for release. Is generally suitable for most catchments. Warning that the IFD surface is made up of point rainfall and many types of events so it might not represent a realist surface particular on large catchments
Accounting for spatial variability between events

ensembling spatial patterns. For large studies and particularly large catchments it is important to understand the extent of spatial variability between events. Where topography is dominant or large events are generally produced by a single rainfall mechanism there is likely to be only moderate variability between events but for some catchments large events can have significantly different spatial variability. Spatially mapping rainfall depths for 5-10 largest events will generally provide a good understanding of variability and can be used for ensemble modelling. Such an approach will also confirm the suitability of the gridded IFD surface.

Where rain gauge networks are dense it is clear that there is significant spatial variability between events in some locations on even small catchments. In most locations there is insufficient data to locally characterise this variability. Where it is important to understand how spatial variability will affect performance or to analysis performance of the system and not just a single location it is possible to use spatial patterns and even spatial time slices in analysis. Where insufficient local data is available it is possible to use spatial patterns from the short duration ARF project in design. These patterns can be normalised by accounting for any IFD gradient and then orientated with local IFD gradient. Such approaches need careful application.
